newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: FOCUS-Manila shares seen regressing further.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-Manila shares seen regressing further.

text.p: Philippine shares dipped at the close on Friday in a session marred by heavy foreign selling and analysts said the negative sentiment on the property and banking sectors is likely to prevail next week.
"More and more foreign investors are jumping into the bandwagon that says the property sector remains vulnerable," said Raul Ruiz, vice-president at Sun Hung Kai Securities.
Fears the property sector will follow Thailand's property slump that had an adverse effect on their banking sector have been sending local property and banking stocks tumbling.
Industry and government officials including President Fidel Ramos have said the Philippine property sector was not headed for a crash.
Leading the losers on Friday were Empire East Land Holdings Inc and its parent Megaworld Properties & Holdings Inc.
The announcement by Empire East of a buy back of its own shares lifted the stock in mid-session but failed to sustain the gains at close.
The most heavily traded issue for the day, Empire, finished 60 centavos lower at 5.20 pesos while its parent Megaworld shed 30 centavos to 5.40 pesos.
The market also saw a sell-off of mobile phone company Pilipino Telephone Corp due to poor first quarter earnings result.
Value turnover was moderate at 2.3 billion pesos.

"The mood is still very much on the selling side. Comparison of the property market with Thailand is exerting a huge impact on sentiment," said Nathan Lozada, assistant vice-president at Philippine Asia Equity Securities.
Sun Hung Kai's Ruiz said the release of blue chip Philippine Long Distance Telephone Co's (PLDT) first quarter earnings on Monday, if above expectations, would cheer an otherwise dull market.
"The index will likely move sideways while waiting for further corporate results. We will also follow the Dow's pace," said Leila Calderon, senior investment analyst at Asian Capital Equities.
The main index will likely trade within the 2,850 to 2,990 band, traders said.
"We look forward to first quarter profits of food and telecommunications companies to save this dull market," All Asia Securities research head Helen Alvarez said.
